questions.question: He is so pigheaded you can’t reason with him.
questions.description: Here so modifies the adjective pigheaded. Only an adverb can modify an adjective.

questions.question: Sailing alone around the world was quite a pilgrimage.
questions.description: Quite is an adverb indicating degree. It shows to what extent.

questions.question: The admiral was always nonchalant in the face of danger.
questions.description: Always is an adverb of time. It answers the question when.

questions.question: A person’s outward appearance was formerly thought to reveal his character.
questions.description: Formerly is an adverb of time. Most words ending in ly are adverbs.

questions.question: Wearing nothing but blue clothing is only one of her peculiarities.
He was seen driving northward.
questions.description: Words indicating place are adverbs.

questions.question: I have told you this twice.
questions.description: Twice is an adverb of frequency. It answers the question how often.

questions.question: That day he arrived late.
questions.description: Here late modifies the verb arrived. Hence it is an adverb.

questions.question: I have already spoken to him about this.
Luckily we escaped unhurt.
My dog understands everything. He is almost human.
questions.description: Here the adverb almost modifies the adjective human.

questions.question: I am fully prepared for the examination.
questions.description: Here the adverb fully modifies the adjective prepared.

questions.question: Surely you are not going out in that torn coat?
questions.description: Most words ending in –ly are adverbs.

questions.question: You can always come and stay with us if you want to.
questions.description: Words that say how often something happens are adverbs.

questions.question: Have you ever played rugby?
questions.description: Words that say how often something happens are adverbs.

questions.question: Your bicycle just needs some oil.
questions.description: Just is an example of a focusing adverb because it points to one part of a clause.

questions.question: The flight has obviously been delayed.
questions.description: Most words ending in -ly are adverbs. Obviously is one of them.

questions.question: She is my mother, but she is also my best friend.
questions.description: Words like also, as well and too are adverbs.

questions.question: She has a new hairstyle every week.
questions.description: Most words indicating time and frequency are adverbs.

questions.question: The invitees have already turned up.
questions.description: Words like already, soon, last, just and still are all adverbs.

questions.question: You have definitely been working too hard.
questions.description: Here too modifies the adjective hard. A word modifying an adjective is an adverb.

questions.question: She speaks English remarkably well.
questions.description: Here the words well and remarkably are both adverbs.

questions.question: We did not achieve much improvement in sales last year.
questions.description: Time words are all adverbs.

questions.question: This time tomorrow I will be happily working in my garage.
questions.description: Time words are adverbs. Most words ending in -ly are also adverbs.
